column6: Police dispersal of Mungiki prayer gathering
column7: Police forcibly dispersed a prayer gathering of hundreds of Mungiki members in a Nairobi slum a week after President Moi ordered a crackdown. Police used force, including rubber bullets and live ammunition, injuring dozens and arresting 23 attendees.

column6: Vigilante gangs kill at least 25 people in Kariobangi
column7: Vigilante gangs linked to ethnic groups and politicians killed at least 25 people in the Kariobangi area. Police arrested 31 suspects but did not prosecute them.
column8: Vigilante gangs vs residents; police responders

column7: During the campaign leading up to the November 2005 constitutional referendum, clashes between supporters and security forces turned violent. At least seven people were killed and hundreds of people chased riot police from Nairobi’s Kibera slum and attacked a truck driver suspected of ballot box fraud.

After the disputed December 27, 2007 presidential election, protests and ethnic attacks broke out across Kenya. Government banned public gatherings and police used live ammunition to disperse demonstrators. Over 1,000 people were killed and up to 500,000 displaced.
column8: Opposition supporters vs security forces and rival ethnic groups

column6: Police break up constitutional reform protest
column7: Police in Nairobi used tear gas and water cannons to break up a peaceful protest by several hundred demonstrators demanding a referendum on constitutional reforms. President Kibaki said reforms would be put to a referendum only after parliament amended them.
column13: {"event_family": "crackdown", "subtype": "protest breakup", "severity": {"fatalities": null, "injuries_est": null, "arrests_est": null, "property_damage": "low"}, "crowd_est": null, "election_cycle": null}

column7: A prolonged drought across East Africa caused severe food shortages and high food prices. The World Food Programme estimated that 3.5 million people in Kenya needed food assistance, warning that the crisis was the worst in decades.

column6: Central Bank raises benchmark rate to 18%
column7: The Central Bank of Kenya raised its benchmark lending rate by 150 basis points to 18% to tackle inflation and stabilize the shilling. Governor Njuguna Ndung’u said supply shocks and exchange rate risks drove the decision.
Militants from Somalia-based group al-Shabaab attacked Nairobi’s Westgate shopping mall, killing civilians and taking hostages. Kenyan security forces battled the attackers during a multi-day siege.

After the August 2017 presidential election, police cracked down on opposition supporters protesting alleged election fraud. Rights groups reported that at least 33 people were killed in Nairobi, including children and a pregnant woman. The government banned demonstrations in major cities.

Kenya experienced its worst outbreak of desert locusts in 70 years. Swarms of locusts threatened crops and pasture; the UN warned that numbers could grow 500-fold with the rains and appealed for $70 million for aerial pesticide spraying.

column6: Anti-tax hike protests and police crackdown
column7: Opposition leader Raila Odinga organised protests against new tax hikes. Police fired tear gas and fought running battles with protesters in major towns. A coalition of human rights groups reported that police arrested 17 protesters in Nairobi and 11 in other towns, with protesters dragged on the ground.
column9: tax hikes, cost of living, protest

column7: Nationwide protests erupted against the government’s Finance Bill, which sought to raise US$2.7 billion in additional taxes. Rights groups reported that one person was killed and at least 200 injured. Police fired tear gas and water cannons, and more than 100 protesters were arrested across Kenya.

column6: IMF board approves $941 million lending boost
column7: The International Monetary Fund’s executive board approved nearly $1 billion in new funding for Kenya under its existing program, including an immediate disbursement of about $624.5 million to ease fiscal pressures.

column6: Drought’s long-term economic hardship contributes to 2023 anti-tax protests
column13: {"source_type": "shock", "source_id": "shk006", "target_type": "incident", "target_id": "inc012", "relation": "amplified", "mechanism_note": "The 2011 drought and subsequent food shortages contributed to long-term economic hardship, which amplified public resentment over tax hikes in 2023.", "confidence": 0.3, "evidence_refs": ["\u3010845798080440888\u2020L71-L100\u3011", "\u3010145052926800530\u2020L184-L213\u3011"]}

column7: Kenya’s 2000/2001 budget allocated Ksh 266.2 billion, with 94% (Ksh 250.9 billion) for recurrent expenditure and 6% (Ksh 15.3 billion) for development. About 41% went to debt service and 53% to salaries and operations.
The government’s 2024/25 finance bill sought to raise US$2.7 billion in additional tax revenues to close a 200 billion Kenyan shilling budget gap, according to parliament’s budget committee.
